title.justification: The title clearly reflects the paper's focus on the paradigm of application-driven research in machine learning, contrasting it with methods-driven research.
title.quote: In this position paper, we argue that application-driven research has been systemically under-valued in the machine learning community.

extractions.description: This position paper discusses the underappreciated paradigm of application-driven research in machine learning, emphasizing the need for innovation inspired by real-world challenges. The authors contrast this approach with the traditional methods-driven research, highlighting the benefits and potential impact of prioritizing application-driven innovation in both the development of machine learning methods and their real-world applications.

type.justification: The paper is a position paper that presents theoretical perspectives and arguments about the paradigm of application-driven machine learning research.
type.quote: In this paper, we frame the paradigm of application-driven ML (ADML) research, propose where it fits within the ML research landscape, and discuss why it is important not just merely to applications but to advancing ML methods.

name.justification: The paper's primary focus is on paradigms of research within the field of machine learning, specifically contrasting application-driven and methods-driven approaches.
name.quote: We argue that both paradigms contribute significantly to ML research.

name.justification: The paper specifically discusses the paradigm of application-driven machine learning as a core focus, differentiating it from methods-driven ML.
name.quote: We outline and compare the distinguishing features of these two approaches, and why both fall under the broader umbrella of machine learning research.

name.justification: The paper contrasts application-driven research with methods-driven research, highlighting the differences.
name.quote: Methods-driven innovation, in which algorithms are designed based on their performance on standardized benchmarks, and application-driven innovation, in which algorithms are designed to meet challenges faced in real-world problems.

name.justification: The paper refers to Vision Transformers while discussing how methods-driven algorithms can fall short in real-world applications, even against simpler models such as random forests.
name.quote: For example, in many remote sensing problems, a simple random forest approach proves more effective than highly regarded computer vision approaches such as Vision Transformers (Dosovitskiy et al., 2021).

is_contributed.justification: The paper uses Vision Transformers as an example of existing methods-focused research that might not meet application-specific needs, not as a contribution.
is_contributed.quote: For example, in many remote sensing problems, a simple random forest approach proves more effective than highly regarded computer vision approaches such as Vision Transformers (Dosovitskiy et al., 2021).

is_executed.justification: The paper does not mention executing Vision Transformers within their research context. It is referenced as an illustrative example.
is_executed.quote: For example, in many remote sensing problems, a simple random forest approach proves more effective than highly regarded computer vision approaches such as Vision Transformers (Dosovitskiy et al., 2021).

is_compared.justification: The paper uses Vision Transformers as an example without presenting a comparative analysis or results.
is_compared.quote: For example, in many remote sensing problems, a simple random forest approach proves more effective than highly regarded computer vision approaches such as Vision Transformers (Dosovitskiy et al., 2021).

referenced_paper_title.value: An image is worth 16x16 words: Transformers for image recognition at scale
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references Vision Transformers in the context of Dosovitskiy et al., 2021.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For example, in many remote sensing problems, a simple random forest approach proves more effective than highly regarded computer vision approaches such as Vision Transformers (Dosovitskiy et al., 2021).

name.justification: ImageNet is referenced as a well-established benchmark that has been frequently cited and used within ML methods-driven research.
name.quote: Many of the innovations celebrated within the ML community arise through experiments on well-established benchmarks such as ImageNet (Deng et al., 2009).

referenced_paper_title.value: ImageNet: A large-scale hierarchical image database
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references ImageNet in the context of methods-driven ML research and cites Deng et al., 2009.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Many of the innovations celebrated within the ML community arise through experiments on well-established benchmarks such as ImageNet (Deng et al., 2009).

name.justification: MS COCO is mentioned as one of the standard benchmarks in ML, illustrating the methods-driven approach in research.
name.quote: Many of the innovations celebrated within the ML community arise through experiments on well-established benchmarks such as ImageNet (Deng et al., 2009), MS COCO (Lin et al., 2014).

referenced_paper_title.value: Microsoft COCO: Common objects in context
referenced_paper_title.justification: MS COCO is referenced in relation to methods-driven research benchmarks and cited with Lin et al., 2014.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Many of the innovations celebrated within the ML community arise through experiments on well-established benchmarks such as ImageNet (Deng et al., 2009), MS COCO (Lin et al., 2014).

name.justification: OpenAI Gym is cited as an example of a standardized benchmark used in methods-driven ML research.
name.quote: Many of the innovations celebrated within the ML community arise through experiments on well-established benchmarks such as... the OpenAI Gym (Brockman et al., 2016).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references OpenAI Gym in the context of well-established benchmarks for ML, citing Brockman et al., 2016.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Many of the innovations celebrated within the ML community arise through experiments on well-established benchmarks such as... the OpenAI Gym (Brockman et al., 2016).

name.justification: iNaturalist is given as an example of an application-specific benchmark that is more suited for application-driven ML work.
name.quote: An increasing number of application-specific benchmarks, such as iNaturalist (Van Horn et al., 2018) ... have been created, often with considerable time and effort.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references iNaturalist as an example of a benchmark designed for application-driven research and cites Van Horn et al., 2018.
referenced_paper_title.quote: An increasing number of application-specific benchmarks, such as iNaturalist (Van Horn et al., 2018) ... have been created, often with considerable time and effort.

name.justification: ClimSim is mentioned as a specific benchmark designed to reflect real-world data and task properties for application-driven ML.
name.quote: An increasing number of application-specific benchmarks, such as... ClimSim (Yu et al., 2023), ... have been created, often with considerable time and effort.
